title: ‘No smoke without fire’: Buck up, Pakatan or risk losing it all, analysts warn
text:
Prime Minster Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad, Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Wan Azizah Wan Ismail and Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng arrive in Parliament for the tabling of Budget 2020 on October 11, 2019. — Picture by Miera Zulyana

KUALA LUMPUR, Oct 25 — Pakatan Harapan (PH) leaders need to stop attacking each other or risk losing more support and drive away local and foreign investors, analysts have warned.

Referring to the statement issued by PH last week attacking Umno’s former vice-president Datuk Seri Hishammuddin Hussein, political analyst Universiti Sains Malaysia’s (USM) Professor Ahmad Fauzi Abdul Hamid said that rather than heaping blame on the Sembrong MP for allegedly sowing disunity among PH’s ranks, it is even more urgent for the former to put its own house in order.

The joint statement was signed by PH secretariat chief Datuk Saifuddin Abdullah; PKR secretary-general Datuk Seri Saifuddin Nasution and his counterparts from Bersatu and Amanah, Datuk Wira Marzuki Yahya and Datuk Wira Anuar Tahir; and DAP national organising secretary Anthony Loke.

Hishammuddin had since dismissed all allegations hurled at him.

“With PH leaders seen joining hands with Umno and PAS leaders at the Malay Dignity Congress recently, and DAP central committee member Ronnie Liu’s recent swipe at Dr Mahathir, this reflects badly on the cohesiveness of the coalition,” said Ahmad Fauzi.

He then referred to a Malay saying, “kalau tiada angin, masakan pokok bergoyang” or “there is no smoke without fire”, implying that if PH’s internal unity is strong, it should be formidable enough to dispel such notions.

Senior fellow of the Singapore Institute of International Affairs Oh Ei Sun believes it is an open secret that as the discord between Prime Minister Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad and Port Dickson MP Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim over succession persists, both sides are trying to cobble together supporters across the political divide.

“So this is but the latest testimony to such power struggle and by now the public should be quite used to it,” said Oh.

Senior fellow of the Singapore Institute of International Affairs Oh Ei Sun believes both Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad and Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim are trying to cobble together supporters across the political divide as discord over the succession plan persists. — Picture by Yusof Mat Isa More

Whether Hishammuddin’s statement has caused any dent on PH, Oh said the dent has been cumulative.

“I don’t think public care much now for politics. It’s a sense of helplessness.

“The conservative will continue to vote for the rightist Umno and PAS, and the progressive may not be bothered to vote, which would only benefit the conservative camp.

“The statement doesn’t matter. It’s the whole sad scene now, that mainly, PH is not spending much time fixing the economy, but (instead) indulging in power struggles,” he said.

UM associate professor Awang Azman Awang Pawi said that people will continue to support PH as long as they see the ruling coalition make real changes in terms of coming up with economic policies rather than politicking.― Picture by Farhan Najib More
